subsc: Agricultural extension and research,Sub-national government administration,Crops

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is
            satisfactory, having exceeded the level of activities
            expected at appraisal, and the benefit analysis from
            treatments to arable areas, show significant positive
            impacts on farm incomes. Furthermore, the project was
            instrumental in promoting vegetative methods of soil, and
            water conservation. Several key lessons are conveyed by the
            project, namely, that addressing the communities'
            priorities proved successful, for, following the Mid-term
            Review, special attention was given to water supply
            provision for rural communities, in direct response to the
            villagers request. And, while considerations for natural
            breeding centers were geographically correct, the response
            from villagers proved the contrary, for bulls were lightly
            used in the area. A degree of flexibility in project design
            is needed, particularly for participatory projects, for this
            flexibility, enabled the project to be broadened according
            to the communities' needs, consequently, achieving a
            greater community commitment. It is paramount to build, at
            an early stage of the project, an activity, and/or
            investment, as a focus of interest for a village community
            committee to attain success. Consensus build-up in villages
            implies a consuming process to engineer the social aspects
            of a project, thus a pre-construction phase is suggested,
            for full involvement and consultation, and technical
            assistance should be a condition for negotiations.
